bwwExcerpt: “Oh, Mary!” is directed by Sam Pinkleton at a breakneck speed that both allows room for the best jokes to harvest their share of laughter while never letting even the lesser gags land with a thud. The entire cast excels at physical comedy, particularly Escola, whose Mary, after seducing her acting teacher on top of Abraham’s desk, must find a dignified way to descend from it, with ingeniously amusing results. I have a pretty low threshold for the coarseness of much low comedy, and plenty of the humor in “Oh, Mary!” is so low it qualifies as subterranean. But Escola’s brilliantly loopy writing and knockabout performance—which also recalls the great gifts of Carol Burnett—won me over.

garbageFullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/oh-mary-review-cole-escola-mary-todd-lincoln-broadway-9a0803c1

Cole Escola Emilio MadridNew York

The first thing to know about “Oh, Mary!”—if the cacophonous enthusiasm for its off-Broadway run hadn’t reached your ears—is that the play, written by and starring Cole Escola, who portrays Mary Todd Lincoln, is howlingly funny. Also inexpressibly and unabashedly vulgar. If frightfully specific jokes about gay sex might cause pause, either steer clear, or bring many a strand of pearls to clutch.
